nodes.bodyText:
I'm a bit worried that RegexFlags is an ExpandableStringEnum as this may grow unbounded with the number of permutations available and will remain in memory as it is backed by a static dictionary.
@brjohnstmsft does the ordering of the regex flags matter? If not we should sort before joining as that reduces the number of possible combinations that will be stored in static memory.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@
+// Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
+// Licensed under the MIT License.
+
+package com.azure.search.documents.util;
+
+import com.azure.search.documents.models.RegexFlags;
+import java.util.Arrays;
+
+/**
+ * Utility class for {@link RegexFlags} complex operations.
+ */
+public final class RegexFlagsUtils {
+
+    /**
+     * Combines a list of {@link RegexFlags} into one separated by "|".
+     * E.g. {@code "CANON_EQ|CASE_INSENSITIVE|COMMENTS"}
+     *
+     * @param regexFlags A list a {@link RegexFlags} to combine.
+     * @return New combined {@link RegexFlags} separated by vertical bar.
+     */
+    public static RegexFlags combineRegexFlags(RegexFlags... regexFlags) {

nodes.bodyText: The ordering shouldn't matter, but maybe we should consider modeling the flags properties of PatternAnalyzer and PatternTokenizer as collections instead of introducing this combining primitive? I believe @xirzec is taking this approach in TypeScript.

nodes.bodyText: @sima-zhu If you model flags as string collections, you'll need to implement the splitting logic for deserialization anyway. This should be done sooner rather than later.

nodes.bodyText: Should add some tests that target RegexFlagsUtils directly.
This won't be null safe which is different behavior than before.
Yes, it will throw NPE. Is it better to make it silent if pass null?
null was an allowable configuration before, this changes it so that once this is set you can never clear it out.
This API may be better as setFlags(RegexFlags... flags).
The reason I choose this because we do not need to convert if passing RegexFlags.values()
Would this be a common scenario though? Also, I think this would be likely to fail as values() would contain all the unioned RegexFlags as well.
@brjohnstmsft what does the service do if the same flag is passed multiple times.
Why are we requiring dataformat.xml?
It is useless. Removed.
What happens if this is called directly instead of being called through serializeWithType? Is it missing the start and end object pieces?

For polymorphism type, it is asking to add TypeIndoName and TypeInfoId for differentiate the base and sub classes.
 ["@odata.type": "#Microsoft.Azure.Search.PatternAnalyzer" ] is added before serialize the rest. These info are inside of the para TypeSerializer
Should any logic in here just be added into serialize and this acts as a proxy to serialize.

Not really, the typeInfoId and typeInfoName is inside of TypeSerializer.
["@odata.type": "#Microsoft.Azure.Search.PatternAnalyzer" ]
What happens if flattenFlags is null?
That's a miss. Will double check null cases for all.
Does this need to live outside of the fields.hasNext() loop?
No. I forgot to move it into method
What if stopwords is null?
Then the check of  "stopwords".equals(field.getKey()) will return false.

So if the JSON contains the following we'll never have a stopwords field?
{ "stopwords": null }
Double checked code. field.getVaule returns iterator.
Does this need to be escaped?
That's how String.split method works.
What is the output when analyzer is null?

I cannot have the case. Index.setAnalyzer takes list
There is no way to have a null PatternAnalyzer pass in.
I plan to remove it.
Same questions as the other deserializer about flags being null and this needing to be outside of the JSON node loop.
How does asInt() handle if getValue() is null? group is a nullable Integer type so it could come back as null from my understanding.

I don't think the case exists.
If the field value is null, then there is no need to generate field key. If the case exists for required field, then we need to have null or empty checking for the field.
Same questions.
Could we use !field.getValue().isNull()?
"null" is a string type in json
Do we have concern that asInt will return int's default of 0 if the JSON value is null?
Don't know if the service would return this.
Based on the test of null group, service does not return group back if it is null.
!field.getValue().isNull()
